item.title: By: Mark Leusink
item.dc:creator: Mark Leusink
item.description:
<p>I've changed the color schemes in both Sublime and Terminal to use a dark background because I find that easier on my eyes. As a side effect those windows are a lot easier to spot on your desktop.</p>
<p>Besides that:<br />- dual monitors<br />- live reload<br />- using nodemon so you don't have to be in the terminal that much</p>
item.content:encoded:
I’ve changed the color schemes in both Sublime and Terminal to use a dark background because I find that easier on my eyes. As a side effect those windows are a lot easier to spot on your desktop.

Besides that:
– dual monitors
– live reload
– using nodemon so you don’t have to be in the terminal that much

item.title: By: David Newman
item.dc:creator: David Newman
item.description: <p>Can't live with out dual monitors. I had 4 at one time but did not like how the graphics card used 2 monitors as one.</p>
item.content:encoded: Can’t live with out dual monitors. I had 4 at one time but did not like how the graphics card used 2 monitors as one.

item.title: By: Richard Civil
item.dc:creator: Richard Civil
item.description:
<p>Two monitors .. <br />Monitor 1 - wide-screen, holds the browsers<br />Monitor 2 - tall(ish)-screen, holds the designer client</p>
<p>Browser's debugging window doesn't have a "home" monitor - it switches depending on what's being done. If debugging, takes the designer client monitor, if updating code, takes the browser monitor ... I guess I need four monitors ;-) (third for debugging, fourth for non-development work).</p>
item.content:encoded:
Two monitors ..
Monitor 1 – wide-screen, holds the browsers
Monitor 2 – tall(ish)-screen, holds the designer client

Browser’s debugging window doesn’t have a "home" monitor – it switches depending on what’s being done. If debugging, takes the designer client monitor, if updating code, takes the browser monitor … I guess I need four monitors ðŸ˜‰ (third for debugging, fourth for non-development work).

item.title: By: Mark Barton
item.dc:creator: Mark Barton
item.content:encoded:
For me I have 2 monitors – 1 monitor has Chrome running full screen – IDE goes on the other.

Webstorm has a built in terminal for running node.js so its contained within the IDE.

Of course live reload of the browser means I never have to actually refresh the page which is handy.
